## Constantin Heger and Charlotte Brontë in Brussels

In 1842 Charlotte travelled with Emily to Brussels to the Pensionnat Heger, a boarding school run by Constantin Heger (1809–1896) and his wife, Claire. Both were student teachers, Charlotte teaching English and Emily teaching music in return for board and lodging, and in this way they hoped eventually to acquire the language skills they needed to open a school of their own.(no content)The talent displayed by both brought them to the notice of Constantin Héger, a fine teacher and a man of unusual perception.(no content)His was the most-interesting mind she had yet met, and he had perceived and evoked her latent talents. His strong and eccentric personality appealed both to her sense of humour and to her affections.

## Charlotte's Unrequited Passion

The following January Charlotte returned to Brussels alone to take up a teaching post at the school, but she was not happy: she was homesick, and her attachment to Constantin Heger had developed into an unrequited passion that made it impossible for her to remain.(no content)Charlotte wrote four long, very personal, and sometimes vague letters to Monsieur Heger that never received replies. The extent of Charlotte Brontë's feelings for Heger were not fully realised until 1913, when her letters to him were published for the first time.(no content)Charlotte's letters to Monsieur Heger after leaving Brussels are incredibly sad as we know that he never responded to them – they are also incredibly passionate, as in this extract from a letter dated 18th November 1845: 'In a word, tell me what you will, my master, but tell me something. Writing to a former assistant teacher (no – I don't want to remember my position as an assistant teacher, I disown it) well then, writing to an old pupil cannot be a very interesting occupation for you – I know that – but for me it is life itself.

## Heger's Influence on Rochester

Many of the characters featured in the Brontë sisters novels, especially Mr. Rochester in Jane Eyre, were inspired by him.(no content)What is clear is that Rochester was highly influenced by a man who had been in Charlotte's own life: Constantin Heger. A powerful man with undoubted faults, but whose personality drew Charlotte inexorably to him, just as Rochester does to Jane.(no content)Less than a year later Charlotte was writing her first novel, The Professor about an English teacher in Brussels who falls in love with his pupil; shortly after she wrote Jane Eyre, and surely Constantin Heger is writ large across the character of Rochester?(no content)In the novel, Charlotte articulated all the pent-up emotion which had been fermenting in her soul for years. She could not declare her love for M. Heger, a married man, but her heroine could and would. Jane, like Charlotte, took the moral line and fled from temptation. But Jane Eyre, unlike Charlotte, could eventually return and have a happy ending with the man she loved.

## Literary Transformation

Charlotte returned to Haworth in January 1844, and later used her time in Brussels as the inspiration for some of the events in The Professor and Villette.(no content)The biography is frank in places, but omits details of Charlotte's love for Constantin Heger, a married man, as being too much of an affront to contemporary morals and a likely source of distress to Charlotte's father, widower, and friends.(no content)It is hard to avoid the conclusion that, in her depiction of this relationship, Charlotte Brontë was expressing some of her fantasies about Constantin Heger, her "maître" in Brussels. Through Frances Henri's suffering, and her eventual triumph over the schemes of Mlle Reuter, Brontë could play out a dream of what might have been; here, true merit might defeat hypocrisy, and the professor clasp his pupil in a warm embrace.

The story of Charlotte Brontë's relationship with Constantin Heger is one of unfulfilled passion that found its expression in her literary works. Her unrequited love for her married teacher in Brussels became the emotional foundation for the passionate romance between Jane Eyre and Mr. Rochester, transforming personal heartbreak into one of the greatest love stories in English literature.
